1.name: Lightning
1.description: Lightning caused fires are notable as they can be a double edge sword in terms of their benefits to the natural habitat and its unexpected occurrence. These fires can help clear unwanted foliage and can often be contained to a specific area by natural barriers. Lightning begins to form as a result of static charges in rain clouds. As winds reach a certain speed in the atmosphere it causes clouds that are inside it be chaotic and less controlled. The water droplets at the bottom of the cloud are then lifted to the top and freeze over because of the colder atmosphere. At this point electrons are stripped off due to the cloud now pushing the ice/hail from the top. This results in a polar balance of a cloud with a positively charged top and negatively charged bottom. When the fields become strong enough it causes the atmosphere to become an insulator to the point where it overpowers the atmosphere leading to a lightning being formed.
details: Two types of lightning: Cold and Hot Lightning.
Difference between the two is the duration of the lightning and how intense the voltage.
Most lightning caused fires usually start due to longer lasting hot lightning bolts.
From 1975 to 2015, lightning caused 82% of the area burned in the Northwest Territories.
In Alaska of 2015, lightning caused 99% of the area burned.

2.name: Equipment Use
2.description: As defined by the state of California, the definition of equipment use caused fires consists of fires started by the use of electrical or mechanical equipment. This broad definition also includes equipment that is both stationary or portable.
details: Equipment malfunction accounted for 72,701 acres burned in California in 2015 alone.
Usually occurs as a result of equipment getting old and its functions begins to be faulty.

3.name: Smoking
3.description: Fires that occur as a result of smoking tobacco or other material like cigars and others. This includes matches as well as the other heat sources used in smoking.
details: Since 1980, the number of smoking caused wildfires have gone down by 90%.
Reasons accounting for the decreased rate include national requirements for less fire-prone cigarettes, decline in number of smokers, and better overall understanding of the causes of wildfires.
Investigators have developed better ways to tell how a wildfire started.
Cumulative effect of this lower smoking caused wildfire rate is that across 12 different U.S. states, over $3.5 million in fire-fighting/rebuilding costs were avoided.

4.name: Campfire
4.description: These types of fires are generally caused by a campfire. This includes campfires and lanterns that are often used for cooking, warmth, lighting, or other purposes. They are primarily outdoors and not near a building, mobile home, or other vehicular dwelling.
details: Campfire caused fires accounted for 1/3 of the 33,700 human caused wildfires from 2006 to 2015.
In the same decade, 73,110 were human caused wildfires
In 2016, the Roaring Lion Fire burned nearly 8,500 acres before being contained.
Often occurs when campfires are left unattended and it spreads via strong winds into nearby wooded areas.

5.name: Debris Burning
5.description: Fires caused by burning trash, refuse, slash, rights-of-war, or rangeland. It can also be debris that is permitted to be burned.
details: Contributes to the statistics of wildfires caused by humans.
Starts the most human-caused fires with a rate of 29% of all human caused fires.

6.name: Railroad
6.description: Fires occurring due to railroad related reasons like railroad rolling stock from a speeder, locomotive, or rail car.
details: Sparks from railroads have been noted to cause wildfires.
From 1992 to 2015, 33,455 wildfires were caused by railroads.

7.name: Arson
7.description: Human caused fires that were deliberately, willfully, and maliciously started to burn or attempt to burn structures, forest land, or other property.
details: In California, almost 95% of fires are started by people and 7% of those are arson.
Depending on the case, even those who mistakenly start a fire are held criminally liable.
Education is the key to lowering the rates of arson caused fires.

8.name: Children
8.description: Fires caused by children usually due to the same reasons as other human caused fires.
details: Most fires caused by children happen as a result of them playing with fire.
From 2007 and 2011, annually 49,300 fires involved children playing with fire were reported.
This led to an average 80 deaths, 860 injuries, and $235 million in property damage.

9.name: Miscellaneous
9.description: These type of fires were started by events/activities that cannot be categorized.
details: From 1992 to 2015, this accounted for 323,805 fires.

10.name: Fireworks
10.description: Fires that are caused by adults/children playing with fireworks. This includes unintentional fires and playing with fire causing devices.
details: Highest rate occurs during the 4th of July holiday in the United States.
During this time, fireworks were the heat source in 30% of all non-trash outside or unclassified fires.

11.name: Powerline
11.description: Fires that are caused by powerline hardwire, pole or tower, and conductors.
details: At least 17 major wildfires in Northern California in 2017 were caused by powerlines.
Some solutions are beginning to develop whereby powerlines would be dug underground in fire risk areas.
These are often destructive fires as powerlines tend to stretch in long distances often passing large areas of fire risk zones.

12.name: Structure
12.description: Fires that start in a building or residential home.
details: From 1992 to 2015, this accounted for 3796 fires, which is a lower number compared to other causes.

13.name: Missing/Undefined
13.description: Missing reason on the cause of the fire.
details: From 1992 to 2015, this accounted for 166,723 fires.
